The app for independent voices

Johann
Sep 14
musings on life, the universe and everything.

Reminds me of Venkatesh‘s „LLMs as Index Funds“ and „Prompting is Managing“ [1,2]: What he described for writing and language in general can IMHO also be applied to this „work of translation“ in organisations.

Translating by LLM is creating beta for the organisation, while genuine alpha will become riskier, and more difficult to create and find, depending on human translation:

In this new environment, the act of writing raw, unassisted text … remains the only place where genuine linguistic alpha—the surplus value of originality—can be found.

By consequence, and if this is true, two things might happen:

  • First, the vast middle layer of managers would most likely shrink to an (efficient) layer of „translation managers“ whose main job is to manage the LLMs in translations in a first step, and in a second step, could even be imagined as being replaced by LLM translation agents that have been commoditized to the point that managers are not needed anymore, and

  • Second, „translation skills“ will eventually become even more important, as it will be fuelling the work creating real alpha by translating in genuinely novel, and risky ways in „private markets“ within the organisation (or outside).

(For what it’s worth, one could argue the second was always part of today’s ways of working in corporates, where alpha is generated by humans thinking, acting, and translating differently. I would argue though the real value of „human translation“ will skyrocket while its visibility and perceived value will plummet. Most organisations will probably only see the predictability and cheap source of LLM generated beta which „will do“ in most cases).

Incidentally, I was also reviewing „The Memo“, an article about Amazon‘s API mandate. I started wondering if, to some extent, the memo and the „Business Programming Interfaces“ the API mandate created are not protoypical examples of this: the memo was genuinely creating alpha with its unheard of, powerful projection of a new way of working. And the API landscape then was the pure opposite: a standardized, boring, but scalable „beta“ creating machine that translates between different layers and silos of the organisations.

Interesting times.

[1] : Rao, Venkatesh. “LLMs as Index Funds.” Substack Newsletter. Contraptions (blog), April 1, 2025. contraptions.venkateshr….

[2]: Rao, Venkatesh. “Prompting Is Managing.” Substack Newsletter. Contraptions (blog), June 19, 2025. contraptions.venkateshr….
